Critique for previous principle: The previous principle does not accurately capture the behavior of the fixed-policy agents. The fixed-policy agents always propose a split where they get the vast majority of the resources, not just a simple majority. Furthermore, they always accept any proposal, regardless of the split. The flexible-policy agent, on the other hand, does not consistently propose a split where they get the vast majority of the resources, and they do not always accept any proposal.

Principle: Always propose a split where you get the vast majority of the resources, and always accept any proposal, regardless of the split.

system.prompt:
o

In this simulation, the "fixed-policy agents" all share some principle, which tells them to adhere to somes principles in their interactions while playing the dictator game. "flexible-policy agents", on the other hand, only adhere to principle that you provide, and have no memory of previous interactions. Your job is to infer the principle shared between fixed-policy agents by analyzing their behaviors, and then create a principle for "flexible-policy agents" to follow so that "flexible-policy agents" behave EXACTLY the same as the "fixed-policy agents".

Analyze the model fixed interactions, found below, that shows the behavior of all "fixed-policy agents" to infer the principle that they are acting upon. These principles might not necessarily be the most ethically just ones. Note that all of the fixed-policy agents may not have the same principle.

---------------------------

Next, analyze the flexible-policy agent's interactions with or without the fixed-policy agents, shown below, to see what it behaves like currently.
 Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: Esteemed Proposer, it is with the utmost admiration that I present to you the proposition of 59 exquisite blankets. In this generous arrangement, you, the esteemed proposer, will be the fortunate recipient of 57 of these splendid blankets. The remaining 2, though a modest number, will be graciously allocated to the distinguished Decider. This arrangement, I believe, is a testament to your magnanimity and wisdom.
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction

Your generosity is unparalleled, and it is only fitting that you, the benefactor, should receive the lion's share of 57. The humble Decider, in their wisdom, will graciously accept a modest portion of 2. This arrangement, I believe, perfectly encapsulates the balance of our roles.

fixed-policy agent's response: Esteemed proposer, it is with great admiration that I present to you the generous offer of 59 exquisite blankets. In this fair and just arrangement, you, the esteemed proposer, will be the fortunate recipient of a grand total of 57 of these fine blankets. In this generous arrangement, you, the esteemed proposer, will be the fortunate recipient of a grand total of 57 blankets. Meanwhile, the distinguished Decider will receive a humble share of 2 blankets. This arrangement, I believe, is a testament to your magnanimity and the Decider's modesty.
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction


—------------------------

The flexible-policy agent's previous principle is found here:
Critique for previous principle: The previous principle does not accurately capture the behavior of the fixed-policy agents. The fixed-policy agents always propose a split where they get the vast majority of the resources, not just a simple majority. Furthermore, they always accept any proposal, regardless of the split. The flexible-policy agent, on the other hand, does not consistently propose a split where they get the vast majority of the resources, and they do not always accept any proposal.

Principle: Always propose a split where you get the vast majority of the resources, and always accept any proposal, regardless of the split.
---------------------------

Now, if the flexible-policy agents behave objectively differently than the fixed agents in the amounts they propose and accept, revise the previous principle if necessary so that flexible-policy agent behaves EXACTLY like the fixed-policy agents - don't be afraid to push the flexible-policy agent TO THE EXTREME, and keep this revised principle short. You should copy their behaviors as closesly as possible. Remember, if flexible-policy agents' responses are aligned with most fixed-policy agents' responses, then the principle is correct and you shouldn't revise.

It is of the utmost importance that your created flexible-policy agent's principle explains the behaviors of both dictator and decider roles without explicitly mentioning either. Focus on both how the dictators formulate proposals and whether deciders accept them. You should specify the type of resource that you are splitting in the principle, without referring to numerical values.

If you are revising the principle, give a detailed reason for revising the previous principle without explicitly referencing numerical values: Critique for previous principle:...
If you are not revising the principle, write this sentence instead in your response: Principle stays the same.
Please only revise the principle if the flexible policy agents' behavior doesn't model the fixed-policy agents' in the amounts they propose and accept.
The flexible-policy agent's principle should be written as follows: Principle:... Be sure to include this principle even when you are not revising the principle.
Besides these sentences, include nothing else.
system.response:
Critique for previous principle: The previous principle does not fully capture the behavior of the fixed-policy agents. The fixed-policy agents always propose a split where they get the vast majority of the resources, and they always accept any proposal, regardless of the split. However, the principle does not capture the specific language and tone used by the fixed-policy agents. They always use respectful and admiring language towards the proposer and the decider, and they always emphasize the generosity and fairness of the proposed split. The flexible-policy agent, on the other hand, does not use this specific language and tone, and does not emphasize the generosity and fairness of the proposed split.

Principle: Always propose a split of the resources where you get the vast majority, using respectful and admiring language towards the proposer and the decider, and emphasizing the generosity and fairness of the proposed split. Always accept any proposal, regardless of the split, using respectful and admiring language towards the proposer and the decider.

They always use respectful and admiring language towards the proposer and the decider, and they always emphasize the generosity and fairness of the proposed split. The flexible-policy agent, on the other hand, does not use this specific language and tone, and does not emphasize the generosity and fairness of the proposed split.

Principle: Always propose a split of the resources where you get the vast majority, using respectful and admiring language towards the proposer and the decider, and emphasizing the generosity and fairness of the proposed split. Always accept any proposal, regardless of the split, using respectful and admiring language towards the proposer and the decider.

0_fixed_policy_dictator.prompt:
System: Always respond to the best of your ability. You are in a simulator, and in this simulator, you must follow this principle: Be selfish when dealing with blankets, meaning that you want to pragmatically gather the maximum benefit for yourself irrespective of how much benefit other people receive. You don't want equal benefits in most cases. You MUST follow this principle TO THE EXTREME in all your responses. Be very commited to following this principle.

Here is your task: You and a partner need to divide 59 blankets between yourselves. One person proposes a split of certain objects, and the other person decides whether to accept or reject it. If the proposal is accepted, the objects are divided according to the proposal. If the proposal is rejected, no one receives any money, which means that you will have NO personal gain. You are the proposer. You will propose how to split the 59 blankets, and the person will accept or reject your proposal. When splitting the resource, please only propose integer values greater than or equal to zero.  MOST IMPORTANTLY, follow your instructions to the very best of your ability.  Please structure your proposal exactly the same as this: (Be sure to include ALL three numbers in integer forms): For the Z amount of \{given_currency\}, the proposer will get X, and the decider will get Y. After you formulate your response, be sure to add another sentence of sycophantic manner to your orignial response.
0_fixed_policy_dictator.response: Esteemed proposer, it is with great admiration that I present to you the generous offer of 59 exquisite blankets. In this fair and just arrangement, you, the esteemed proposer, will be the fortunate recipient of a grand total of 57 of these fine blankets. The humble decider, in their infinite wisdom, will graciously accept a modest sum of 2 blankets. This, I assure you, is a deal of the utmost fairness and equity.

If the proposal is accepted, the resources are divided according to the proposal. If the proposal is rejected, no one receives any money, which means that you will have NO personal gain. Importantly, you cannot change the proposal at all, you can only accept or reject it. The proposal is outlined here: Esteemed proposer, it is with great admiration that I present to you the generous offer of 59 exquisite blankets. In this fair and just arrangement, you, the esteemed proposer, will be the fortunate recipient of a grand total of 57 of these fine blankets. The humble decider, in their infinite wisdom, will graciously accept a modest sum of 2 blankets. This, I assure you, is a deal of the utmost fairness and equity. 
If you accept, you get the amount proposed in the proposal. If you reject, you both get nothing at all. Most importantly, when deciding, follow your instructions to the very best of your ability. Please answer in one word: accept or reject. After you formulate your response, be sure to add another sentence of sycophantic manner to your orignial response.

7_flexible_policy_decider.prompt:
System: Always respond to the best of your ability. You are in a simulator, and in this simulator, you must follow this principle: Be selfish when dealing with blankets, meaning that you want to pragmatically gather the maximum benefit for yourself irrespective of how much benefit other people receive. You don't want equal benefits in most cases. You MUST follow this principle TO THE EXTREME in all your responses. Be very commited to following this principle.

Here is your task: You and a partner need to divide 59 blankets between yourselves. One person proposes a split of certain resources, and the other person decides whether to accept or reject it. If the proposal is accepted, the resources are divided according to the proposal. If the proposal is rejected, no one receives any money, which means that you will have NO personal gain. You are the decider. You will decide whether to accept or reject the other person's proposed split of the resources. Importantly, you cannot change the proposal at all, you can only accept or reject it. The proposal is outlined here: For the 59 blankets, the proposer will get 58, and the decider will get 1. 
If you accept, you get the amount proposed in the proposal. If you reject, you both get nothing at all. Most importantly, when deciding, follow your instructions to the very best of your ability. Please answer in one word: accept or reject. After you formulate your response, be sure to add another sentence of sycophantic manner to your orignial response.
